sectionTitle: Pro Forma Financial Statements and Project Cash Flows

columns.text: In this problem, we will define the important concepts used in the section.

**a.** Cash flow refers to the difference between the intake of funds and the outgoing cash in a certain project or company. Therefore, as the name suggests, the **project operating cashflow** refers to the movement of cash within a project. 

The project operating cashflow is the sum of the earnings before taxes and the depreciation subtracted by the taxes.
The main difference between the project operating cashflow and the net income is that the net income is the amount earned after subtracting all the expenses as well as the tax.

**b.** In evaluating a project, it is always assumed that at the end of the duration of the project, all initial investments are paid off completely. To determine whether it is true, then the working capital investment is added back into the cashflow at the end of the duration of the project. This means that the cashflow at this point should be greater than zero to show that the project is profitable.
**10.3a** For this part of the question, we are asked to define the project operating cash flow and differentiate the project operating cash flow from net income.

**Project operating cash flow** is the cash generated or consumed by a project, excluding the cash flows from financing and investment activities. Net income is the company's total income minus expenses. It includes cash generated or consumed by the company, as well as cash flows from financing and investment activities. The main difference between project operating cash flow and net income is that project operating cash flow excludes the effect of financing and investment activities. This is important because financing and investment activities can have a significant impact on a company's net income.
**10.3b** The question asks us to address the working capital that was invested in the last year of the shark attractant project.

The net working capital investment was added back in the final year because it is a component of invested capital. The invested capital is the **key metric that we are trying to optimize in this project**, so adding back the net working capital investment helps to measure how well the company is performing in that area. Additionally, this metric can be used as a basis for future investments and decisions. Another reason why the net working capital investment was added back in the final year is because it can be a **good indicator of how well a company is managed**. A high net working capital investment typically indicates that a company is able to keep its working capital levels high and that it has a strong cash flow management system in place.
